user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue:
```c
void UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_CONSTANT);
    if (StubPtr != NULL)
    {
        UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue:
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
...
static void UT_ClearStubEntry(UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr)
{
    /* Be sure to call free() on any malloc'ed buffers before clearing */
    if ((StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER || StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER) &&
        StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr != NULL && (StubPtr->ModeFlags & UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF) != 0)
    {
        free(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr);
    }
    memset(StubPtr, 0, sizeof(*StubPtr));
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code fragments. The code contains only standard C constructs (typedefs, pointer usage, arithmetic, while(1) loop, if, function calls, calls to standard library functions free/memset). There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm, typeof, __builtin_*, nested functions, statement expressions, designated initializers with non-standard syntax, GCC/Clang-style extension keywords, or other vendor-specific keywords. The identifiers like cpuaddr, uint32, UT_EntryType_t, and UT_EntryData_t are typedefs (type aliases) and not language extensions themselves; their definitions are not shown here, so unless cpuaddr or those typedefs expand to a compiler-specific builtin type or extension (which would be visible in their definitions), there is nothing to report. Therefore no code fragments are flagged for further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
